<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Lock_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_Lock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_lock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_lock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Temporarily Disable/Defer thread cancellation.
         * Note that OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl() calls write() which is a cancellation point.
         * So if this calling task is canceled, it risks leaving the BSP locked.
         */
        pthread_setcancelstate(PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE, &OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState);
    }
}
```

explanation: OS_BSP_Lock_Impl has no formal parameters, so there are no function parameters in this function that could be modified (MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 concerns modification of a function's parameters). The only pointer usages are arguments to library calls: pthread_mutex_lock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex) and pthread_setcancelstate(PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE, &OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState). These pass addresses of global objects (not function parameters). MISRA 17.8 allows the object referred to by a pointer parameter to be modified; it only forbids modifying the pointer parameter itself inside a function. The code in this function does not assign to any parameter nor to any pointer parameter variable. BSP_DEBUG is defined empty, so it introduces no hidden parameter modification. Therefore there are no fragments in the provided code that need investigation for Rule 17.8.
